About
About
As an operating partner to Founders and leaders of Series A to C startups, I specialize in translating high-level strategies and AOPs into executable quarterly plans, and building accountability through OKRs, metrics, and structured reviews. I've also managed business critical projects for Founders such as entity restructuring and due diligence for fund raise. 
Have worked with a diverse set of start-ups across industries in India. 
Before making the move to the start-up ecosystem, have worked with large corporates on building business plans and strategies, financial modelling, and business process reengineering.

Siddharth M.
Siddharth M.
   • 3rd+
Verified • 3rd+
Execution Excellence at xto10x | ex-Deloitte | IIM Lucknow
Execution Excellence at xto10x | ex-Deloitte | IIM Lucknow
2mo • 
 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
𝟯𝟬 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁-𝘂𝗽𝘀. 𝟰𝟬 𝗳𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀. 𝟭 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗻 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺: 𝘁𝗼𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘆 '𝘆𝗲𝘀𝗲𝘀' 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗲𝗻𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀.

Had a blast speaking at, IIM Bangalore’s incubation cell, last week on how OKRs can help startups stay focused.
A room full of 40-odd early-stage founders — the energy was something else!

What struck me most was how, despite working on wildly different problems — 𝙛𝙧𝙤𝙢 𝙫𝙖𝙘𝙘𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙨-𝙖𝙨-𝙖-𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙞𝙘𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙙𝙧𝙤𝙣𝙚 𝙩𝙚𝙘𝙝𝙣𝙤𝙡𝙤𝙜𝙮 — these 0→1 founders all faced one common challenge: 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗮𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗻𝗼.

It showed up on loop during my interactions:
- Building every feature that every customer asked for but does it solve the core problem?
- Debating endlessly: Should we spend months polishing the product or hit the ground now and get raw customer feedback?
- Shiny object syndrome: Jumping at every partnership opportunity while getting sidetracked from the next growth milestone.
- Pivoting the product (or launching multiple products) after every customer conversation, making it impossible to build depth and momentum in any one area.

It’s not a lack of effort — if anything, 𝙞𝙩’𝙨 𝙩𝙤𝙤 𝙢𝙪𝙘𝙝 𝙚𝙛𝙛𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙨𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙 𝙩𝙤𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣. In meme parlance - "Attack 100%, damage 0%".

𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗮𝘆 𝗻𝗼, 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟯–𝟰 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗹𝘆 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗲𝗹𝘀𝗲 𝗮𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝗶𝘀𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗯𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗺𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗿 𝗴𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝘂𝗰𝗸 𝗶𝗻 𝗯𝘂𝘀𝘆𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸.

OKRs help you do exactly that: Pause. Prioritize. Focus.

Thanks to the amazing team at NSRCEL for invitingto the event, and to all the founders — wishing you sharp focus and big wins ahead! 🚀

…more
